channel.title: The New Yorker
channel.description: Stay up to date on everything happening in The New Yorker and on newyorker.com.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2006 CondeNet Inc. All rights reserved.
channel.dc:creator: newyorker.com
channel.dc:subject: everything
channel.dc:rights: Copyright 2006 CondeNet Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Come Play with “The Shining”
item.description: “The Shining,” released in May, 1980, has always been seen as Stanley Kubrick’s pulpiest and most commercial venture. It’s not just that it’s a horror film. (All of Kubrick’s works, really, are horror films.)...
item.dc:creator: Bill Wyman

item.title: Toyo Ito’s Pritzker Win
item.description: The new Pritzker Prize winner Toyo Ito (who will receive his medal in a May ceremony at Boston’s John F. Kennedy Presidential Library) is a seventy-one-year-old Japanese architect with a distinguished forty-year record of substantial and influential buildings, some of them much admired. And yet, as much as Ito’s Pritzker acknowledges his indisputable skill and endurance, the prize also illuminates some of the deep weirdness of architecture as a profession.
item.dc:creator: Thomas de Monchaux

item.title: A Frenzy of Threat
item.description: A menacing tone was set as soon as the first lighting cue came up, in silence: eight narrow strips of light crossing the floor from end to end, which created a sharp, forbidding environment, a trap that awaited unsuspecting victims.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Boynton

item.title: “V.” at L: Pynchon’s First Novel Turns Fifty
item.description: To read “V.” today is to experience Pynchon anew. Blast through the multilayered densities of “Gravity’s Rainbow,” “Mason & Dixon,” and “Against the Day,” and you have a young Cornell graduate, an engineer from Long Island, writing with an earnestness you might not have expected, about a world he could never recover.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan

item.title: Trailer Trash
item.description: It seemed as though we had survived a dark time, and made it safely to the other side, when roughly two minutes and twenty seconds of the new “Star Trek” trailer had elapsed without...
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: Book News: Amazon Recommends, Cat-Like Tread
item.description: Amazon has bought the book-recommendation site Goodreads. An interview with Renata Adler about the writing life, rereading your old work, and why so much writing today is “like a race to join the herd...
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Political Scene: Moving Gay Marriage Forward
item.description: This week, the Supreme Court heard oral arguments in two cases dealing with gay marriage: the challenges to California’s Proposition 8 and the federal Defense of Marriage Act. On the Political Scene podcast, Jeffery Toobin and Margaret Talbot talk with Dorothy Wickenden about how the Court might rule in each case and what the decisions could mean for marriage equality.
item.dc:creator: Matthew McKnight

item.title: Hey Look!
item.description: The New Yorker cartoonists and comics fans Benjamin Schwartz and Liam Francis Walsh took a trip to the Society of Illustrators to see The Art of Harvey Kurtzman. (Through May 11th, Society of Illustrators, 128 East Sixty-third Street.)
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Schwartz and Liam Francis Walsh

item.title: Gay Political Power—or Good Survival Skills?
item.description: Following Wednesday’s Supreme Court arguments on the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act, there has been a lot of discussion of whether gays and lesbians have become so politically powerful as to hardly warrant the safeguards of the equal-protection clause of the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Richard Socarides

item.title: Street of the Iron Po(e)t, Part VI
item.description: When the telephone rings, I snatch it up, thinking it will be S calling. Is he the being I’ve been waiting for? When he visited last week, he brought The New Yorker and together we sat on the front steps of the Panthéon, from which one can see out over all of Paris, and slowly we translated the magazine pages, laughing at each other’s errors.
item.dc:creator: Henri Cole

item.title: Video: How Does Telecommuting Work?
item.description: In February, the Yahoo C.E.O. Marrisa Mayer banned employees from working at home. The decision, which bucked the growing trend of telecommuting in the corporate world, drew a great deal of criticism. James Surowiecki recently weighed in.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Book News: Acing Nabokov, Reel Love
item.description: The Argentinian illustrator Isol has won this year’s Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award, the biggest prize in children’s literature. Edward Jay Epstein recalls how watching the movie instead of reading the book got him an...
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Why the Gay-Marriage Fight Is Over
item.description: Gay people deserve changes in the law—now. But the extraordinary subtext of the two days of arguments was that everyone knew those changes were coming, with or without the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Toobin

item.title: A Better Quality of Agony
item.description: Readers who are looking for a neat story of loss and redemption, a simple narrative arc, catharsis on the cheap, will find no such thing in Sonali Deraniyagala’s memoir about losing her family in Sri Lanka’s 2004 tsunami: the particularity of Deraniyagala’s suffering, and the intensity with which she feels it, is immense. But something does shift in the course of the narrative.
item.dc:creator: Teju Cole

item.title: Video: The Oral Arguments in the DOMA Case
item.description: The Supreme Court released audio of the oral arguments on the Defense of Marriage Act, which we’ve combined with the work of courtroom artists. Watch and listen to excerpts of some of the day’s most dramatic exchanges.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Painting the Internet Pink
item.description: It seems safe to say that the Justices of the Supreme Court, currently weighing the fate of the Defense of Marriage Act, have not spent their time basking in the soft glow cast by an array of pixels depicting a pink equal sign against a red square backdrop, a symbol that is currently blanketing social-media networks like Facebook and Twitter.
item.dc:creator: Matt Buchanan

item.title: Justice Kennedy’s DOMA Problem
item.description: Ever since the Supreme Court agreed to hear the two same-sex marriage cases that are before it this week, Court-watchers have been pointing to Justice Anthony Kennedy as the key to any victory for marriage-equality proponents.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Talbot

item.title: The Stop-and-Frisk Challenge
item.description: Fighting crime in New York City—like in any large metropolis—comes with many challenges. There are more than eight million residents in the five boroughs, and many hundreds of thousands more people travel to and...
item.dc:creator: Matthew McKnight

item.title: What We’re Reading: James Lasdun, Paula Fox, George Antheil
item.description: George Antheil’s autobiography, published in 1945, is called Bad Boy of Music. It’s an incredibly entertaining, restless traipse and sometime skirt-chase set between the Wars, and it takes the reader from the factory neighborhoods of Trenton, New Jersey, to the inner circles of European high culture, and back west to the hills of Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: For Edith Windsor, a Good Day in Court
item.description: While it looked as if there were probably a majority of Justices willing to overturn DOMA, the more important thing for the future will be the grounds upon which they do so.
item.dc:creator: Richard Socarides

item.title: Book News: Bully Writing, the Fitzgerald Feud
item.description: Anti-bullying books (and their related anti-bullying campaigns) are experiencing a spike in production and popularity. F. Scott Fitzgerald and Zelda’s contentious literary relationship is brought to light in books due for release in the...
item.dc:creator: Rega Jha

item.title: “Renoir”: A Portrait of the Artist as an Old Man
item.description: Gilles Bourdos’s new film, “Renoir,” is openly a celebration of sensuous ease and calm. It’s an idyllic, low-intensity movie set in what appears, literally and symbolically, to be the last bastion of the nineteenth century.
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Video: The Oral Arguments in the Prop 8 Case
item.description: The Supreme Court released audio of the oral arguments on Proposition 8, California’s gay-marriage ban, which we’ve combined with the work of courtroom artists. Watch and listen to excerpts of some of the day’s most dramatic exchanges.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: The Number: 851,000
item.description: The Manischewitz Company’s unleavened hegemony remains intact—as of last year, it controlled forty per cent of the Passover matzo market—thanks to Behr Manischewitz, who helped transform a small Cincinnati matzo factory into a global brand by redefining matzo itself.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fromson

item.title: Would the Justices Rather Not Rule on Prop 8?
item.description: The most important thing anyone needs to know about Tuesday’s Supreme Court oral arguments on the constitutionality of Proposition 8, California’s same-sex marriage ban, is this: veteran Supreme Court watchers and gay-rights advocates alike came away with the impression that Associate Justice Anthony Kennedy, the swing vote, was, in the words of one advocate, looking for a way not to decide.
item.dc:creator: Richard Socarides

item.title: Can the Supreme Court Hurry Love?
item.description: There is a clear constitutional issue at the heart of Hollingsworth v. Perry—namely whether barring same-sex couples from marrying is a violation of equal protection. But Tuesday’s arguments were a reminder that there is a swirl of bigger questions which come up every time that issue is argued in court.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Talbot

item.title: Neil Freeman’s Alternative Geography
item.description: Two Sundays ago, the artist and urban planner Neil Freeman stood in front of a vacant lot in Bushwick, Brooklyn, beneath the elevated J train and across the street from an apartment blasting Colombian cumbia music. “This is the geographic center of New York,” he said to me and five others shivering in the pre-spring cold.
item.dc:creator: Jason Fagone

item.title: Spitballing Indy
item.description: For several days in 1978, George Lucas, Steven Spielberg, and the screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan worked through an idea Lucas had for a film called “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” and they recorded the sessions. And there’s a transcript.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Radden Keefe

item.title: The Methodless Method
item.description: The summers I spent at my grandmother’s house were defined by reading—particularly reading, with extreme interest and feeling, the oddest and most unsuitable things I could find lying around: an ancient issue of Good...
item.dc:creator: Alice Bolin

item.title: Lost and Found: Unearthing the Sixties Songs of Tandyn Almer
item.description: I had never heard of Tandyn Almer. And so when I saw that the excellent record label Sundazed was releasing an album of Almer’s demos, I stared at the name for a while. Tandyn Almer. It didn’t even seem like a real name so much as a Scrabble spill.
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: Looking Back at Bob and Ray
item.description: Today is the ninetieth birthday of Bob Elliott, of the classic American comedy duo Bob and Ray. For half a century, starting in 1945, Bob and his partner Ray Goulding, who passed away in 1990, created a unique kind of spoof comedy.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rothman

item.title: The “Master” Letters of Margaret Fuller and Emily Dickinson
item.description: Fuller’s “Master” letter does not help to resolve the questions that surround Dickinson’s gnomic metaphors, masochistic tone, and intended recipient. But it speaks eloquently to what Susan Sontag calls “a common reality”: the predicament of a woman isolated by her singularity, whose mind was free, but whose heart and body yearned for surrender.
item.dc:creator: Judith Thurman

item.title: Boris Berezovsky: An Oligarch Dies
item.description: Boris Berezovsky was a man of grand, Shakespearean scope. And Putin’s Russia is no country for grand personalities.
item.dc:creator: Masha Lipman

item.title: Book News: Proust’s First Poem, Travel Apps
item.description: Ann Napolitano visits Flannery O’Connor’s childhood home in Savannah. “Is it too much of a stretch to say that deconstruction was at some level an allegory of personal exclusion?” Emily Eakin on how Derrida’s...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Rescuing the Eisenhower Memorial
item.description: The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial would take up much of a four-acre plot across the street from the National Air and Space Museum, which itself sits on the increasingly cluttered National Mall, and would be dominated by four eighty-foot metal curtains showing scenes from Eisenhower’s life. It has managed to achieve something rare in Washington: in true bipartisan spirit, almost everyone hates it.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Frank

item.title: Passover with the Bronfmans
item.description: Bronfman said that he wrote his version of the Haggadah, the text that guides the Passover meal while telling the story of the Jews’ exodus from Egypt, with children in mind. Illustrated with watercolors by his wife, Jan Aronson, it includes quotations from such goyim as Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ralph Waldo Emerson, and there is no Hebrew in it.
item.dc:creator: John Ortved

item.title: As Syria Bleeds, Lebanon Reels
item.description: Wouldn’t it be ironic if the popular awakening sweeping the Middle East had the unintended effect of undermining the one established Arab democracy? On Friday, Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati resigned. His departure followed...
item.dc:creator: Dexter Filkins

item.title: Cover Story: New Yorkers in Love
item.description: When you look at New Yorkers, you can see some things that simply don’t change. Witness the slideshow below of loving couples in Art Deco New Yorker covers from the nineteen-twenties.
item.dc:creator: Mina Kaneko and Francoise Mouly

item.title: Reconciliation at My Lai
item.description: One day that summer Mike Boehm went to his mother’s attic, where his medals from Vietnam were stored, and threw them in the garbage. He informed the veterans’ affairs office that the G.I. Bill was “blood money” and that he could no longer accept it.
item.dc:creator: Dan Kaufman

item.title: Book News: Willa Cather’s Letters, @DavidGrann
item.description: More than five hundred of Willa Cather’s letters will be published in an anthology next month after decades of tight archival restrictions. “If print could talk, it would surely be telling the world, Mark...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: This Week in Fiction: Sarah Braunstein
item.description: In your story, “Marjorie Lemke,” which appears in this week’s issue, we meet a woman who considers herself a loser. Where did things go wrong for Marjorie Lemke?
item.dc:creator: Willing Davidson

item.title: Steve Coll: Why the Administration targeted a C.I.A. officer.
item.description: In 2007, John Kiriakou was settling into a lucrative life as a former spy. His fourteen-year career as a C.I.A. officer had included thrilling, if occasionally hazardous, tours as a specialist in counterterrorism. In Athens, in 1999 and 2000, he recruited several foreign agents to spy for the United . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Steve Coll

item.title: Russell Platt: New classical albums from Annie Gosfield and Lee Hyla.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">John Zorn’s Tzadik label has never courted celebrity. Its catalogue consists largely of albums by talented avant-garde composers who don’t naturally seek the limelight, and that’s a welcome philosophy. A great example is Annie Gosfield, whose fourth disk for the . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Russell Platt

item.title: Out Loud: Skeptically Yours
item.description: Here, Michael Schulman listens to and explains a few of the songs that made Time Minchin famous in his native Australia and in the U.K. Also, a phone call with Minchin himself.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Michael Schulman: An Australian comic translates Roald Dahl’s “Matilda” for Broadway.
item.description: Three years before Roald Dahl died, he was stumped by a five-year-old. Like many of his protagonists, Matilda Wormwood was a precocious youngster surrounded by monstrous adults and grotesque peers. But in early drafts of “Matilda,” Dahl had painted her as a wicked child who uses . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Michael Schulman

item.title: Goings on About Town: Readings and Talks
item.description: goatTitle-->STRAND BOOK STORE<!--/goatTitle--> Three spring readings here celebrate the tenth anniversary of the Poetry Society of America’s Chapbook Fellowship. The first features Dan Chelotti and Yusef Komunyakaa, who will read and discuss their work. Alice Quinn, the executive director of the Society, will introduce the poets . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->APUTUMPU FESTIVAL<!--/goatTitle--> This small weekend gathering, now in its second year, brings more than two dozen local up-and-comers to a handful . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Movies
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENING<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->BLANCANIEVES<!--/goatTitle--> A version of “Snow White” set in nineteen-twenties Spain. Directed by Pablo Berger; starring Maribel Verdú and Daniel Giménez Cacho. In Spanish. Opening March 29. (In limited release.)
<!--goatTitle-->FAMILY WEEKEND<!--/goatTitle--> A comic drama, about a . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Classical Music
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPERA<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN OPERA<!--/goatTitle--> March 27 at 7:30 and March 30 at 8: The tenor José Cura is reportedly causing a stir in the title role of Verdi’s “Otello”—not so surprising, since it’s the calling card worldwide . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Above and Beyond
item.description: goatTitle-->“RUNNING LATE WITH SCOTT ROGOWSKY”<!--/goatTitle--> This biweekly live talk show features guests from the worlds of media and entertainment. Rogowsky, a young comedian, has been hosting these shows around town for about eighteen months, and he has managed to secure the likes of Chris Elliott, Rachel . . .
